Award.AwardTitle: Recent Developments in Noncommutative Algebra and Related Areas
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the conference "Recent developments in noncommutative algebra and related areas", which will be held March 17-19, 2018 at the University of Washington, Seattle, Washington. The purpose of the conference is to survey recent developments and to chart new paths for further progress on several topics of active current interest in noncommutative algebra, with broad connections to other subjects such as combinatorics, algebraic geometry and mathematical physics.

The conference will bring together researchers who work in noncommutative algebra and related areas, namely, algebraic geometry, representation theory and topology. The focus of the conference will be new research directions of several important topics such as noncommutative algebraic geometry, Hopf algebras and quantum groups, noncommutative invariant theory, higher category theory, and algebraic aspects of mathematical physics. Special effort will be made to bring together a group of junior researchers, women and underrepresented minorities, who are currently working in different directions, and to engage them in interdisciplinary activity through collaboration. More information can be found at the conference website: https://sites.math.washington.edu/~zhang/SeattleRDncAR2018/index.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference ``Recent Developments in Noncommutative Algebra'', held at the University of Washington in March of 2017, provided an opportunity for both young and established researchers in noncommutative algebra, mathematical physics and derived noncommutative algebraic geometry to come together and share their most recent work. The speakers and attendees were diverse in age, gender and research area, and the conference provided fertile ground for collaboration and discussion between researchers who otherwise may not have interacted to this degree. In total, nine fifty-minute talks were given by established mathematicians, seven twenty-five-minute talks were given by younger researchers, and thirteen five-minute talks were given by graduate students. This  NSF grant, as well as some funding from other sources, allowed the conference to fund travel and lodging for all of the fifty-minute and twenty-five minute speakers, as well as many of the graduate students. Numerous breaks were also provided, with refreshments, which helped create a relaxed atmosphere for attendees to speak informally to one another about their research. 

 

The conference also hosted several career development and social events to help support young mathematicians. There was a panel discussion allowing graduate students and postdocs to  hear from, and ask questions of, academic mathematicians at several different points in their careers (e.g. tenure, pre-tenure, full professor, emeritus). This panel discussion focused on the topics of applying for jobs and grants, what a career in academia looks like, and general advice for success in mathematics. A member of the local Association for Women in Mathematics chapter also organized an AWM dinner aimed at fostering connections between women in the various subdisciplines represented at the conference. The conference also hosted a special presentation on ``Computations in Algebra'', given by Frank Moore (of Wake Forest University) and John Palmieri (of University of Washington). This presentation allowed Moore and Palmieri to describe the use of computer algebra systems like Macaulay2 and SAGE/CoCalc, respectively. Finally, as is typical at such events, an informal conference dinner was organized at a local restaurant and attended by the vast majority of the conference participants.
